body:
### Problem

Random lines are not drawn for a fraction of a second when editing a file. Line above is partially cut off. Contents below, including cursor line, are shifted one line up and then down.

### Steps to reproduce

minimal.lua
```lua
local lines = [==[
hl("aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa")
hl("bbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbb")
]==]

vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'Test', { bg = 'green' })

local ns = vim.api.nvim_create_namespace('minimal.lua')
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('TextChanged', {
  pattern = '*',
  callback = function()
    vim.api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(0, ns, 0, -1)
    vim.api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(0, ns, vim.fn.line('w0') - 1, 0, {
      virt_text_pos = 'right_align',
      virt_text = { { ' ', 'Test' }}
    })
  end
})

vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, true, vim.split(lines:rep(50), '\n', { plain = true }))
vim.cmd('set ft=lua')
```

```console
nvim --clean -u minimal.lua
```

```
L
3j
3k
```

and then press `ddu` repeatedly.

See video:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0ef1b751-529d-421c-9d50-dd69e99319cc

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/14374058-690a-4655-a39e-8bec75e72c18)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5c8c3f8e-27a4-4ea2-8b44-dec4f686751b)

and

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/69358dfb-3774-48eb-a49c-08a0d07d5d4a)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/29bb5f99-9201-4ad7-a558-66c91da20bd6)

### Expected behavior

Lines should not disappear.

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.11.0-dev-1177+gcdc9baeaf8

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no

### Operating system/version

Ubuntu 24.04

### Terminal name/version

XTerm(390)

### $TERM environment variable

xterm

### Installation

build from source

comment_data.body:
I know the minimal.lua is not very minimal. 

I bisected and found that the bug was introduced in cdc9baeaf89eb09f08427a09e3a0f86d56dcc812
I was about to say: nvim-treesitter should not be required for this.

I would be interested in figuring out how the bisected commit resulted in what is shown in the video, but I have yet to be able to reproduce.

Can revert if this isn't resolved when the milestone is due I guess.

> but I have yet to be able to reproduce.

You can try this `minimal.lua`. For me, this triggers the bug almost every time (on one of `hl(0, ...` lines).

```lua
local lines = [===[

{
    "jake-stewart/multicursor.nvim",
    branch = "1.0",
    config = function()
        local mc = require("multicursor-nvim")
        mc.setup()

        local set = vim.keymap.set

        -- Add or skip cursor above/below the main cursor.
        set({"n", "x"}, "<up>", function() mc.lineAddCursor(-1) end)
        set({"n", "x"}, "<down>", function() mc.lineAddCursor(1) end)
        set({"n", "x"}, "<leader><up>", function() mc.lineSkipCursor(-1) end)
        set({"n", "x"}, "<leader><down>", function() mc.lineSkipCursor(1) end)

        -- Add or skip adding a new cursor by matching word/selection
        set({"n", "x"}, "<leader>n", function() mc.matchAddCursor(1) end)
        set({"n", "x"}, "<leader>s", function() mc.matchSkipCursor(1) end)
        set({"n", "x"}, "<leader>N", function() mc.matchAddCursor(-1) end)
        set({"n", "x"}, "<leader>S", function() mc.matchSkipCursor(-1) end)

        -- Add and remove cursors with control + left click.
        set("n", "<c-leftmouse>", mc.handleMouse)
        set("n", "<c-leftdrag>", mc.handleMouseDrag)
        set("n", "<c-leftrelease>", mc.handleMouseRelease)

        -- Disable and enable cursors.
        set({"n", "x"}, "<c-q>", mc.toggleCursor)

        -- Mappings defined in a keymap layer only apply when there are
        -- multiple cursors. This lets you have overlapping mappings.
        mc.addKeymapLayer(function(layerSet)

            -- Select a different cursor as the main one.
            layerSet({"n", "x"}, "<left>", mc.prevCursor)
            layerSet({"n", "x"}, "<right>", mc.nextCursor)

            -- Delete the main cursor.
            layerSet({"n", "x"}, "<leader>x", mc.deleteCursor)

            -- Enable and clear cursors using escape.
            layerSet("n", "<esc>", function()
                if not mc.cursorsEnabled() then
                    mc.enableCursors()
                else
                    mc.clearCursors()
                end
            end)
        end)

        -- Customize how cursors look.
        local hl = vim.api.nvim_set_hl
        hl(0, "MultiCursorCursor", { link = "Cursor" })
        hl(0, "MultiCursorVisual", { link = "Visual" })
        hl(0, "MultiCursorSign", { link = "SignColumn"})
        hl(0, "MultiCursorMatchPreview", { link = "Search" })
        hl(0, "MultiCursorDisabledCursor", { link = "Visual" })
        hl(0, "MultiCursorDisabledVisual", { link = "Visual" })
        hl(0, "MultiCursorDisabledSign", { link = "SignColumn"})
    end
}

if true then return end

local vim = vim -- fix lsp warning

local done = false
local function setup()
    if done then return end
    done = true

    vim.api.nvim_exec_autocmds('User', { pattern = 'load-multicursor' })
end
local function map(keys) return function() setup(); return keys end end

local m = require('mapping')

local opt = { remap = true, silent = true, expr = true }
m.n('<C-j>', map('<C-down>'), opt)
m.n('<C-k>', map('<C-up>'), opt)
m.n('<C-h>', map('<S-left>'), opt)
m.n('<C-l>', map('<S-right>'), opt)
m.n('<C-n>', map('<Plug>name'), opt)
m.x('<C-n>', map('<Plug>name'), opt)

vim.api.nvim_exec2(
    [==[
    let g:VM_maps = {}
    let g:VM_maps['Find Under'] = '<Plug>name'
    ]==],
    { output = false }
)

local function initColors()
    local p = require('rose-pine.palette')
    vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'VM_Mono'  , { bg = p.love, fg='#ffffff' })
    vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'VM_Extend', { bg = p.pine, fg='#ffffff' })
    vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'VM_Cursor', { bg = p.iris, fg='#21202e' })
    vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'VM_Insert', { bg = '#ffffff', fg='#21202e' })
end

initColors()

local group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('MulticursorHighlighting', { clear = true })
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('ColorScheme', {
    pattern = '*',
    callback = initColors,
    group = group
})
]===]

vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'Test', { bg = 'green' })

local ns = vim.api.nvim_create_namespace('minimal.lua')
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('TextChanged', {
  pattern = '*',
  callback = function()
    vim.api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(0, ns, 0, -1)
    vim.api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(0, ns, vim.fn.line('w0') - 1, 0, {
      virt_text_pos = 'right_align',
      virt_text = { { ' ', 'Test' }}
    })
  end
})

vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, true, vim.split(lines:rep(1), '\n', { plain = true }))
vim.cmd('set ft=lua')
vim.api.nvim_feedkeys(vim.api.nvim_replace_termcodes('j%5<C-e>', true, true, true), 'n', false)
```

It looks like the grid is shown in the middle of redraw. I don't see any invalid state when redraws finish. But I do see 2 intermediate states that could, if merged, produce the artifact.

Which function sends the grid to UI?

Wait for me this _doesn't_ reproduce on `master` but does reproduce _after_ `git revert` cdc9baeaf89eb09f08427a09e3a0f86d56dcc812...
I forgot I had the revert applied when trying to reproduce. Did you somehow bisect where this was fixed or am I tweaking😆

> Wait for me this _doesn't_ reproduce on `master` but does reproduce _after_ `git revert` [cdc9bae](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/cdc9baeaf89eb09f08427a09e3a0f86d56dcc812)... I forgot I had the revert applied when trying to reproduce. Did you somehow bisect where this was fixed or am I tweaking😆

I guess it could happen both before and after the commit. 
For me, it happens consistently after the commit, and I couldn't make it happen before the commit.

> It looks like the grid is shown in the middle of redraw. I don't see any invalid state when redraws finish. But I do see 2 intermediate states that could, if merged, produce the artifact.
> 
> Which function sends the grid to UI?

`tui->grid.cells` is fine at the start/end of `tui_flush()`es in the non `--embed` process.

It looks like something scrolls the screen up one line and then the entire screen is rerendered at the original position after deleting a line, and somehow the intermediate state is visible.

Although buffer chunks in `flush_buf()` don't have intermediate states.

There is no difference in neovim's buffers in `flush_buf()` whether the issue occurs or not.
And it doesn't seem to be related to `tui->overflow`.

Scroll redrawing for deleted/inserted lines indeed bypasses `flush_buf()`, see `win_scroll_lines()` -> ... -> `tui_grid_scroll()` instead. 

(I still haven't seen any issues on `master` when trying to reproduce, only pre- cdc9baeaf89eb09f08427a09e3a0f86d56dcc812 do I notice a problem, although I now see it might be a slightly different problem from the one shown in your video.
Still happens on current commit 4a706a70928231643e1a3f3fcf785de7aa930f8b `NVIM v0.12.0-dev-124+g4a706a7092`
Another issue that I assume is related is that `vim.hl.on_yank` highlight randomly disappears before its timeout.

labels.description: wrong behavior that was introduced in a previous commit (please bisect)
labels.name: bug-regression

labels.description: issue has been tracked to a specific commit
labels.name: has:bisected

title: line disappears when editing buffer
